data.title: Don't install devtron when toggling DevTools
data.body:
Refs: #11750

Instead of automatically installing devtron after toggling the developer tools, we just bundle it in Atom and let people install it manually when they need to debug the application by executing the following snippet in the console:

```
require('devtron').install()
```

/cc: @lee-dohm

data.title: replace _.extend in favor of Object.assign
data.body: Since Chromium 45 supports native `Object.assign` for merging objects. Let's get rid `extends` from `underscore` in favor of native method.

data.title: Sign Windows builds with Squirrel for MSI compatibility
data.body:
This switches us from signing directly with the Windows SDK to using Squirrel. This is necessary as Squirrel builds both the atomsetup.exe and the atomsetup.msi (which contains atomsetup.exe) so signing atomsetup.exe ourself is too late if we want to distribute the msi.

This is a little convoluted as we currently support remote URLs for keys to enable signing keys to not be checked in which Squirrel does not support so we continue to do that in our signing step but leave the actual signing to Squirrel.

data.title: replace OSX window title bar with custom title-bar
data.body:
This pull request is intended to naively implement a custom titlebar on OSX.

I've included fallback styling to match El Capitan's titlebars, which is probably not necessary as I modified the four included themes to provide their own titlebar styling. I'll create PRs for these in their respective repositories if this PR gets considered.

I'd like to hear your thoughts on the implementation, I just banged on the code until it worked ðŸ˜ 

This is what it looks like by default: 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/170500/15407444/211946aa-1e0b-11e6-871b-4f332cbab894.png)

This is the titlebar provided by one-dark-ui, with the oceanic-next syntax
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/170500/15407534/ad8b0c4a-1e0b-11e6-842e-de6df82d5e15.png)

This is one-light-ui, with the atom-light syntax
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/170500/15407555/c5222ba4-1e0b-11e6-9aeb-2f7693e20a2d.png)

Things left to do:
- [x] âœ… specs

This is a partial continuation of https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/10208 albeit without the combined title-bar-and-tabs functionality, for which this would be the groundwork. (As requested in https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/4599 for example.)

data.title: Tabbing appears to not follow visual order
data.body:
### Description

The tab order appears to now be following visual order when switching using the `pane:show-next-item` or `pane:show-previous-item` commands (regardless of the shortcut used to initiate this command)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open a number of tabs
2. Close a tab (not the last one)
3. Open a new tab

**Expected behavior:** The tabs should switch as order of display.

**Actual behavior:** The tabs switching to the new tab before the tab which was the last in the list before the new tab was opened.
### Versions

Atom: 1.7.3
APM: 1.9.2
Running Mac OS X 10.11.4

data.title: Atom needs to handle large files better.
data.body:
When you open a large file in Atom, the whole editor freezes up while it loads the whole file.

This is neither desirable or acceptable. Can't it just load a portion of the file? Like the head or something.

And for 1 infinite line files (generated files), set a line length limit. Then as the user scrolls, read more data and display it.

data.title: add includeMarkerText param to highlight decorations
data.body:
When passed in the decoration properties, this flag will render the text of the marker into the highlight's regions. This allow a highlight decoration to have a background color and a contrasting enough color for the text on top of it.

Actually, when using highlight decorations, we can't really use them if we have a background color that may conflict with the foreground color: 

![styles_less_ __users_cedric_development_ruby_leclerc-es-v2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/247140/15386192/abdbf8d8-1da6-11e6-8509-2bd86cf380cb.png)

It means than these decorations, while essential in any good text editor, can be only used to outline/underline a marker.

Now, with the `includeMarkerText` flag enabled the following is now possible: 

![json_form_js_coffee_ __users_cedric_development_ruby_leclerc-es-v2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/247140/15386270/29eab5a2-1da7-11e6-9b90-09b443d956f5.png)

It's far from an ideal solution, but given than since this problem was first reported (almost two years ago), we still don't have a proper solution for that issue. This one is at least simple, don't cost much performance-wise and can be reverted/changed quite easily as well.

data.title: fix spec toShow()
data.body:
This patch fixes toShow for correct matching not hidden element.

Previos realization has some problems:

1) `element.style.display` is '' (empty string) if property setted via not inline style. We should use `getComputedStyle` for correct detecting css rules instead of style property.
2) Checked only `block` and `inline-block`. What's about `table`, `inline`, `flex`, etc? It's enough just check for not `none`
3) Ignored `style.visibility` and `hidden` property

data.title: Unfold tree (unfold everything under definition) feature
data.body:
When I open a file, I first use the `Editor: Fold All` command to get a high-level view of the file, and then locate the function I want to look into. Now, to actually look at the code of that function I unfold the line where the function begins by clicking the little `>` arrow to it's left.

The problem is when functions contain other functions, then all the sub-functions are by default folded too. So to see the full code of the sub-function, I need to manually click and unfold each of them, and possibly the sub-sub-functions too. In a language like OCaml, where it's common coding practice to have many nested `let ... in` structures, this makes it a huge pain to use the folding feature.

**Suggested enhancement**

Instead of toggling between fold and unfold when clicking the arrow, instead cycle through "fold", "unfold", and "unfold entire tree".

**Current and suggested behavior**

Currently, after a fold-all, my code looks like this:

```
> def foo(n): ...
```

If I click the arrow once, I get:

```
 def foo(n):
>    def bar():...
>    def boo():...
```

And to see everything I need to click and unfold `bar` and `boo` manually. Clicking the arrow next to `foo` once more just returns it to the folded state in the first code block above.

Instead, I suggest that clicking the `foo` the second time produces this instead:

```
 def foo(n):
     def bar():
         pass
     def boo():
         pass
```

**Why would the enhancement be useful to most users**

It would save users of languages like Ocaml many clicks, and they'd be able to easily see the entire code of a function.

This feature exists in Emacs, for example, the default behaviour of <Tab> folding in org-mode does exactly this.

**Atom Version:** 1.7.3
**OS and Version:** OS X 10.10.5

data.title: All files open as empty buffers via gvfs on Linux
data.body:
### Description

I am trying to use Atom to work on files on a machine I am connected to via SFTP/SSH.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Using Ubuntu, connect to a remote machine (e.g. via SFTP) using the file manager.
2. Open Atom.
3. "Open Folderâ€¦" and select a directory on the remote machine in the dialog. (Here the file tree will correctly show the files and directories on the remote machine, and the window title will include something like `/run/user/1000/gvfs/sftp:host=svante.mit.edu/home/pnk/igsm`.)
4. Open a file from the file tree.

**Expected behavior:** Contents of the file are shown.

**Actual behavior:** An empty buffer is shown.
### Versions

```
$ uname -a && lsb_release -rd && apt-cache policy atom && atom --version && apm --version
Linux khaeru-laptop 4.4.0-22-generic #39-Ubuntu SMP Thu May 5 16:53:32 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

data.title: Mixing Arabic characters and curly brackets confuses LTR/RTL and closing bracket position & direction
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

When arabic characters are between curly brackets the left to right order is getting confused.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Write the sample text or load a file with the sample text:

```
\textarabic{ Ù…Ø§Ù„ \lala{Ù…Ø§ Ù„}  }
```
1. Put cursor between `}  }`
2. Start writing arabic characters. For example I start writing `Ù‚Ø§`

**Expected behavior:** 
I would expect to see

```
\textarabic{ Ù…Ø§Ù„ \lala{Ù…Ø§ Ù„}  Ù‚Ø§ }
```

or (gimp manipulated image)
![how_it_should_look_like](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1138992/15367152/6f3614ac-1d30-11e6-8013-e00dc3d73ee1.png)

**Actual behavior:**

![animation](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1138992/15367183/8ac1bc08-1d30-11e6-8f77-078b66ab1c10.gif)

```
$ atom --version
```

data.title: Unable to disable 80 char guide
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
  - The `atom` command and `apm` doesn't work on my new machine.
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
  - See note below
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

I'm getting Atom setup on a new machine. I'm trying to get rid of the 80 character guide, but cannot seem to find a way to disable it. 

I thought it used to be in Settings as a checkbox with a value you could adjust for the length, but either my memory is incorrect, or it has been changed. I also checked under the View menu, but there is no toggle for it there, either.

@shiftkey pointed out that on his machine setting `Preferred Line Length` to `0` seems to be doing it, but for me that doesn't actually work as setting a `0` value results in Atom automatically changing the value to `1`, which just overlays the line at the 1 character column.

Even more strange about the previous point is that I don't even have `Soft Wrap At Preferred Line Length` checked, so if anything I would assume that `Preferred Line Length` should not be in effect until this is checked.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Download Atom from Atom.io on a new machine.
2. Open a file.
3. Attempt to turn off the 80 character guide.

**Expected behavior:** I expected there to be a checkbox in `Settings` or a toggle option in the `View` menu to allow me to turn the guide on or off.

**Actual behavior:** I found no way to turn it off after quite some time of looking, resorted to Twitter assuming I was Doing It Wrongâ„¢, and it was suggested this might be a bug.
### Versions

My Atom build is `1.7.3` and I'm on `OSX 10.11.5`

---

Note: This is technically a dupe of https://github.com/atom/settings-view/issues/790, but @shiftkey pointed out that the code is actually [in this repo](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/ca041384fecf8a17bae078d2813fc94a90498bb8/src/config-schema.coffee#L174-L178) so opening here too unsure of where this actually belongs. :grin:

data.title: Tabbing forward and back
data.body:
Atom version: 1.7.3
OS: Ubuntu 14.04 LTS 
(experienced the same behaviour on Fedora 23 with earlier version and 1.8.x beta version)

There are two issues I am having with the tabbing.
The first is that alt-tab chooses the tab on the left side, while alt-shift-tab chooses the tab on the right.
Before recently (not sure when it appeared, I upgraded from 1.6.x and it suddenly started to happen) it worked the opposite and sometimes it works like so.

I tried to override it with the keymap, but it completely fucked up my tabbing navigation, somtimes had to click twice to go to any of the tabs, sometimes once and sometimes it even stuck. (not switching to any tab)

Another issue is that it jumps between tabs.
As an example: say we have 4 tabs
| tab1 || tab2 || tab3 || tab4 |
and I am currently on tab3, pressing alt-tab would open me tab2, pressing again would open tab4 and again will open tab1 and then back to tab3
continuing to press these keys will travel the same way.

I don't know what causes any of two, but it happens randomly, meaning that sometimes it works properly and sometimes it doesn't.

Last but not least, while selecting a file, it opens it in a read mode causing the next file select to take place of the current tab, in other words, won't open in a new tab.
I know that double clicking will open it in write, but can an option be added to disable opening files in read mode completely ?

I am experiencing this issue for a long time, and I thought its minor problem and it will be fixed at some version, but it didn't and it starts to really bother me and makes Atom really uncomfortable to me.

_Side note_: I am not an expert nor package rich user, I only have the Atom setup and minimap and pigments as installed packages.

data.title: Unable to paste text copied with xsel, when it contains over 4000 chars
data.body:
### Description

xsel is a command-line tool to access X clipboard and selection buffers in linux. Things copied with it up to 4000 chars are pasted in atom fine (printf "%04000d" 0 | xsel -ib), but over that it freezes atom (but not sublime or mousepad ..).

xclip is another such terminal clipboard program. Atom can paste things copied with it without a size limit, these commands work:

```
 printf "%04001d" 0 | xclip -selection clipboard -i
 printf "%08001d" 0 | xclip -selection clipboard -i
 printf "%080001d" 0 | xclip -selection clipboard -i
```
### Steps to Reproduce
1. printf "%04001d" 0 | xsel -ib
2. atom --safe .
3. open new tab and paste
4. editor freezes for 30s, popup "Editor is not responding" opens
   1. select keep waiting -> editor unfreezes, no text pasted
   2. select close -> atom closes, output in terminal:

```
/usr/bin/atom: line 98: 29057 Segmentation fault      (core dumped) nohup "$ATOM_PATH" --executed-from="$(pwd)" --pid=$$ "$@" > "$ATOM_HOME/nohup.out" 2>&1
App load time: 372ms
Failed to get crash dump id.
Report Id: 
```
### Versions

`--> atom --version
Atom    : 1.7.3
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1

`--> apm --version
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.11+
git 2.7.4

`--> lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID: Ubuntu
Description:    Ubuntu 16.04 LTS
Release:        16.04
Codename:       xenial

`--> uname -a
Linux . 4.4.0-22-generic #40-Ubuntu SMP Thu May 12 22:03:46 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

`--> dpkg -l xsel
ii  xsel                         1.2.0-2             amd64               command-line tool to access X clipboard and selection buffers

`--> dpkg -l xclip
ii  xclip                        0.12+svn84-4  amd64               command line interface to X selections

data.title: ctrl-alt-cmd-up shortcut not working
data.body:
I'm setting up a new machine from scratch with OSX 10.11.5 and Atom 1.7.3. This happens in safe mode too.

For some reason using `ctrl-alt-cmd-up` doesn't work.

```
'atom-text-editor:not([mini])':
  'ctrl-alt-cmd-up': 'editor:delete-line'
```

I've tried using the shortcut with other functions and it doesn't work either.

```
'atom-workspace atom-text-editor:not([mini])': 
  'ctrl-alt-cmd-up': 'editor:duplicate-lines'
```

If I change to `ctrl-alt-cmd-down` it does work so it may seem like a problem with the key combination.

This used to work... Since this is a fresh machine I don't know whether it's an Atom problem or an OSX one or a combination.

data.title: Force Touch support
data.body:
[Link to Force Touch's Wikipedia article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Force_Touch)
### Description

I'd like to be able to use a Force Touch trackpad to perform some tasks. There could be default ones.

Default actions : 
- Force Click : Go to declaration
- Force Click : Rename in tree-view (would mimic Finder's behavior)
- Force Click : On the gutter to insert a bookmark
- Force Feedback : On end of scrolling (at bottom and top of a file)
- Force Feedback : When moving a tab in the tabs-bar (feedback when the placeholder line moves)

After, an API could be made available to package developers to allow things like : 
- Force Click :  On the minimap to open another split tab of the same file at that place
- etc.

**Expected behavior:** Have an immersive Force Touch experience

**Actual behavior:** No Force Touch support
### Versions

Atom    : 1.7.3
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1

data.title: Module version mismatch when using apm or installing/fetching packages
data.body:
### Description

I am unable to update or install packages or themes using either `apm` or the atom interface.

Specifically, I get the following error:

```
module.js:434
  return process.dlopen(module, path._makeLong(filename));
                 ^

Error: Module version mismatch. Expected 46, got 47.
    at Error (native)
    at Object.Module._extensions..node (module.js:434:18)
    at Module.load (module.js:343:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:300:12)
    at Module.require (module.js:353:17)
    at require (internal/module.js:12:17)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/usr/lib/node_modules/atom-package-manager/node_modules/git-utils/lib/git.js:8:16)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/usr/lib/node_modules/atom-package-manager/node_modules/git-utils/lib/git.js:371:4)
    at Module._compile (module.js:409:26)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:416:10)
```
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open atom
2. Go to _Settings View: Install Packages and Themes_
3. Look on my works, ye Mighty, and despair!

![capture d ecran de 2016-05-17 11-01-17](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/579329/15327227/b361aa3c-1c1e-11e6-8bfe-33b4fec96e89.png)
### Versions

**OS**

Fedora 24 beta, `4.5.4-300.fc24.x86_64`

Output of `atom --version`

```
Atom    : 1.7.3
Electron: 0.37.7
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

Output of `apm --version` give the same error.

I install atom from the `mosquito/atom` copr repo @Â [https://copr.fedorainfracloud.org/coprs/mosquito/atom/]

Does anyone else on @atom/core that has worked with the build more than I have know what's missing here?

data.title: tab type auto works only after reopening the file
data.body:
### Description

tab type auto detects (soft|hard) correctly only after closing file and re-opening it.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open file that contains soft tabs.

![screen shot 2016-05-16 at 4 15 45 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8479569/15289180/798d09d4-1b81-11e6-883e-d63599453570.png)
1. Change soft tabs to hard tabs. (I use tabify)
2. save
3. Create new line, click tab

**Expected behavior:** hard tab created on new line
![screen shot 2016-05-16 at 4 15 11 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8479569/15289209/a6482b34-1b81-11e6-98d7-e6443046bb92.png)

**Actual behavior:** soft tab will be created
![screen shot 2016-05-16 at 4 14 53 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8479569/15289215/b353eaa2-1b81-11e6-8436-6ea75795392b.png)

after closing the file, and opening again, and redoing 4th step, it correctly creates hard tab.
### Versions

OSX 10.11.4

Atom : 1.7.3
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome : 47.0.2526.110
Node : 5.1.1

apm 1.9.2
npm 2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.7.4

data.title: Show folded marker in the first screen row of a soft-wrapped buffer row
data.body:
This fixes a problem (introduced in #11414) in the rendering of the gutter "folded" icon when a line is soft wrapped. In particular, such icon was being shown on the last screen row of the wrapped buffer row rather than on the first one. 

**Before:**
![before](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/15285778/a6f1edc2-1b59-11e6-92ae-5e13e7ce0939.gif)

**After:**
![after](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/15285788/b568977a-1b59-11e6-9e63-f7cf9d0f264d.gif)

/cc: @atom/core

data.title: [Debian] Atom is not minimizing.
data.body:
### Description

I installed Atom (newest version) on Debian 8. My Problem is that whenever i wanna minimize the window only the top bar goes away but the rest of the editor stays in foreground.
Tried it also on another computer with Debian 8...no problem. Maybe it's because of the low resolution, 1376 x 700 something like that.
What can I do?

data.title: Don't render line-numbers corresponding to lines that need measuring
data.body:
~~Depends on atom/text-buffer#156.~~
Fixes #11745.

Rendering line numbers corresponding to lines that need to be measured isn't useful, and it puts unneeded pressure to the DOM. In the process of changing `updateLineNumbersState`, we have also refactored it to stop relying on row ranges being contiguous. This allows that code path to be:
1. Less error-prone, because we were trying to access rows that weren't actually rendered, and thus throwing an exception when measuring non-contiguous screen rows.
2. Tighter, because we can just iterate over each screen row and ask for its soft-wrap descriptor.

/cc: @atom/core
